title: MetOp-SG-A1 and Sentinel-5 launch highlights
summary: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission –  has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time).
detailed_news: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission – has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time) It is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites.

title: EDGX Secures €2.3M to Build AI In-Orbit Data Processing System
summary:
Belgium-based startup EDGX announced on 11 August that it had secured €2.3 million in seed funding to develop a high-performance, AI-capable on-board computer that will process data collected by a satellite’s sensors directly in orbit. Founded in 2023, EDGX is developing its Sterna on-board computer and the SpaceFeather software that will power it. It aims […]
The post EDGX Secures €2.3M to Build AI In-Orbit Data Processing System appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: Belgium-based startup EDGX announced on 11 August that it had secured €2.3 million in seed funding to develop a high-performance, AI-capable on-board computer. The company is currently preparing for its initial demonstration mission, dubbed Early Bird, which is scheduled to launch in February 2026 aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9. According to the company, it has already secured a €1.1 million commercial contract with an undisclosed satellite operator.

title: MetOp-SG-A1 and Sentinel-5 launch on Ariane 6
summary: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission –  has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time).
detailed_news: Europe’s first MetOp Second Generation, MetOp-SG-A1, weather satellite – which hosts the Copernicus Sentinel-5 mission – has launched aboard an Ariane 6 rocket. The rocket lifted off on 13 August at 02:37 CEST (12 August 21:37 Kourou time) It is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites.

title: First MetOp-SG and Sentinel-5 launched
summary: Ushering in a new era of weather and climate monitoring from polar orbit, the first in a new series of satellites, MetOp Second Generation, has been lofted into orbit aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana. As part of this new satellite’s sophisticated instrument package is the new Copernicus Sentinel-5 instrument, which is designed to deliver critical data on air pollutants, ozone and climate-related gases.
detailed_news: First in a new series of satellites, MetOp Second Generation, has been lofted into orbit aboard an Ariane 6 rocket from the European spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana. As part of this new satellite’s sophisticated instrument package is the new Copernicus Sentinel-5 instrument, which is designed to deliver critical data on air pollutants. Each of the three pairs consists of an A-type and B-type satellite. They carry complementary state-of-the-art instruments to provide high-resolution measurements of temperature, precipitation, clouds and winds for weather forecasting and climate analysis. Each MetOp-SG satellite is fitted with an extra thruster, enabling it to self-destruct in Earth’s atmosphere when the mission is complete. Main stage and solid rocket boosters are responsible for the first phase of flight. The stage is powered by the Vulcain 2.1 engine (fuelled by liquid oxygen and hydrogen), with the main thrust at liftoff provided by the P120C boosters. The upper stage will fire two times to reach the required orbit for this mission.

title: ULA launches Vulcan rocket on first Space Force mission
summary: Equipped with four solid-fuel strap-on boosters for additional takeoff power, the 198-foot-tall Vulcan's two methane-fueled BE-4 engines thundered to life at 8:56p.m. EDT, instantly propelling the rocket away from pad 41 at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.
detailed_news: United Launch Alliance fired off it’s first fully operational Vulcan rocket Tuesday. The rocket put on a spectacular sky-lighting show as it roared aloft atop nearly 3 million pounds of thrust. At least two satellites were believed to be on board: one classified spacecraft and an experimental satellite. United Launch Alliance chief executive Tory Bruno spoke with Spaceflight Now’s Stephen Clark at the 32nd Space Symposium in Colorado Springs. ULA President and CEO Tory Bruno said the Vulcan's first stage, using high-performance BE-4 engines, is particularly well suited for launching heavy military payloads into hard-to-reach orbits.

title: ULA’s Vulcan Centaur Lifts Off on First National Security Mission
summary: ULA’s new Vulcan Centaur rocket lifted off on a national security mission for the first time this evening. One payload aboard the U.S. Space Force’s USSF-106 mission is the Navigation […]
detailed_news: The U.S. Space Force’s USSF-106 mission is the Navigation Technology Satellite-3 that is testing new technologies for future satellite navigation systems like GPS. NTS-3 is a small spacecraft on a very big rocket being launched in one of its most capable configurations. The USSF is not saying what else is aboard. ULA ended live coverage of the launch before reaching orbit. After intense debate in the Senate, then-Senator Bill Nelson brokered a deal in 2016 setting limits on the number of RD-180s ULA could buy and how long they could be used for military missions. ULA had already begun working on a new rocket by then, reaching agreement in 2014 with Jeff Bezos’s Blue Origin to build the engines.

title: B1091 “A Heavy Core in Falcon 9 Clothing”
summary:
SpaceX’s recent launch involved another successful landing of its Falcon 9 booster, but this time…
The post B1091 “A Heavy Core in Falcon 9 Clothing” appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: SpaceX’s recent launch involved another successful landing of its Falcon 9 booster, but this time marked a Falcon Heavy center core booster launching and landing as a single-stick Falcon 9 rocket. The booster, designated B1091, powered the KF-02 mission, deploying 24 satellites for Amazon's Project Kuiper broadband constellation into low Earth orbit. The launch occurred on August 11, 2025, at 8:35 a.m. ET from Space Launch Complex 40. SpaceX has repurposed Falcon Heavy side boosters for Falcon 9 missions in the past, including the inaugural Falcon Heavy flight in 2018. The primary deterrent has been the added mass from reinforcements, estimated at 10-20% more than a standard Falcon 9 booster. During its return, observers noticed evidence of the booster’s heavier build during the KF-02 landing.

title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4624-4626: A Busy Weekend at the Boxwork
summary: Written by Alex Innanen, Atmospheric Scientist at York University Earth planning date: Friday, Aug. 8, 2025 We continue to progress through the boxwork structures, arriving today at the “peace sign” ridges we were aiming for in our last drive. We’re spending the first two sols of the weekend at this location, learning everything we can […]
detailed_news: Curiosity has arrived at the “peace sign” ridges we were aiming for in our last drive. The environmental science group (ENV) is also taking a dust-devil movie and a surpahorizon cloud movie. ChemCam will use AEGIS to autonomously pick a LIBS target, we’ll have a 360-degree survey to try to catch dust devils.

title: NASA IXPE’s ‘Heartbeat Black Hole’ Measurements Challenge Current Theories
summary: Written by Michael Allen An international team of astronomers using NASA’s IXPE (Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer), has challenged our understanding of what happens to matter in the direct vicinity of a black hole. With IXPE, astronomers can study incoming X-rays and measure the polarization, a property of light that describes the direction of its electric […]
detailed_news: Astronomers used NASA’s IXPE to measure a 9.1% polarization degree for black hole IGR J17091-3624. The polarization degree is a measurement of how aligned those vibrations are to each other. Despite how bright the corona is, at some 28,000 light-years from Earth, it remains far too small and distant to capture an image of it. IXPE is led by NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. BAE Systems, Inc., headquartered in Falls Church, Virginia, manages spacecraft operations. The Imaging X-ray Polarimetry Explorer (IXPE) is a space observatory built to discover the secrets of some of the most…

title: A Tapestry of Tales: 10th Anniversary Reflections from NASA’s OCO-2 Mission
summary: When woven together, the tapestry of experiences of staff and scientists provide the complete picture of OCO-2. Breathe in… Breathe out. This simple rhythm sets the foundation of life on Earth – and it’s a pattern that a NASA satellite has been watching from space for over a decade. On July 2, 2024, NASA’s Orbiting […]
detailed_news: On July 2, 2024, NASA’s Orbiting Carbon Observatory-2 (OCO-2) celebrated 10 years since its launch. OCO-2 is now viewed as the gold standard for carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) measurements from space. Scientists from around the world have come together to bring the important data from this satellite to the broader community. The first launch in 2009 ended in failure – when a faulty launch vehicle doomed the first OCO to a watery grave. In the aftermath, the OCO community were left in limbo, unsure if the project would survive. OCO-2 can detect the faint glow given off by plants during photosynthesis. This glow offers a fast, sensitive indicator of plant health – see Figure 2 . OCO-2 and MODIS provide a global dataset of plant photosynthesis far beyond what either satellite could produce on its own. OCO-2’s synergy with its A-Train counterpart, the Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) on NASA’S Aqua platform, makes the data even more powerful. OCO-2 and OCO-3 provide complementary perspectives on Earth’s carbon cycle and plant health at space and time resolutions that have not been possible from space before. The satellite's high-precision measurements can now detect CO 2 linked not just to countries, but large cities, industrial zones, and even individual power plants – all while researchers continue perfecting efforts to identify contributions from city sectors. The Total Carbon Column Observing Network (TCCON) of Fourier Transform Spectrometers (FTS) measure CO 2 over snow-covered ground. OCO-2 was being used to develop early drought forecasts. The “ground truth” data collected at these field sites help to ensure that the satellite is accurately measuring “Earth’s breathing” During the 2015–2016 El Niño, large tropical forests temporarily transformed into net carbon sources. OCO-2 captured the increase in atmospheric CO 2 and scientists used this data to refine estimates of how these events contribute to the global carbon budget. Scientists are combining the satellite data with wind models and urban maps to trace CO 2 to its sources.

title: A Gigantic Jet Caught on Camera: A Spritacular Moment for NASA Astronaut Nicole Ayers!
summary: Astronaut Captures Rare Gigantic Jet from Space On July 3, 2025, NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers photographed an extraordinary sight from the International Space Station — a rare gigantic jet, a powerful electrical discharge shooting from the top of a thunderstorm into the upper atmosphere. Often mistaken for sprites, these towering lightning events bridge clouds and space, depositing massive electrical charges. Learn how gigantic jets differ from other Transient Luminous Events and how you can submit your own sightings to Spritacular.org.
detailed_news: NASA astronaut Nichole Ayers captured a rare form of a Transient Luminous Events (TLEs) — a gigantic jet. Gigantic jets are a powerful type of electrical discharge that extends from the top of a thunderstorm into the upper atmosphere. Sprites, on the other hand, are one of the most commonly observed types of TLEs.

summary: LIVE COVERAGE! Vulcan Set To Launch First U.S. National Security Mission
detailed_news: The USSF-106 mission, flying for the U.S. Space Force’s Space Systems Command, is scheduled to lift off tonight from Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Florida. The launch window runs from 7:59 to 8:59 p.m. EDT (2359–0059 UTC), with liftoff targeted within that one-hour period.

title: Hubble Captures a Tarantula
summary: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image captures incredible details in the dusty clouds of a star-forming factory called the Tarantula Nebula. Most of the nebulae Hubble images are in our galaxy, but this nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. The Large Magellanic […]
detailed_news: The Tarantula Nebula is in the Large Magellanic Cloud, a dwarf galaxy located about 160,000 light-years away in the constellations Dorado and Mensa. This image is very close to a rare type of star called a Wolf–Rayet star . Wolf– Rayet stars are massive stars that have lost their outer shell of hydrogen.

title: NASA Roman Core Survey Will Trace Cosmic Expansion Over Time
summary: NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will be a discovery machine, thanks to its wide field of view and resulting torrent of data. Scheduled to launch no later than May 2027, with the team working toward launch as early as fall 2026, its near-infrared Wide Field Instrument will capture an area 200 times larger than […]
detailed_news: The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will be a discovery machine. Its near-infrared Wide Field Instrument will capture an area 200 times larger than the Hubble Space Telescope’s infrared camera. Roman will devote about 75% of its science observing time over its five-year primary mission. High-Latitude Time-Domain Survey will be split into two imaging “tiers” — a wide tier that covers more area and a deep tier that will focus on a smaller area for a longer time to detect fainter objects. The observations will take place in two areas, one in the northern sky and another in the southern sky. There will also be a spectroscopic component to this survey, which will be limited to the southern night sky.

title: Ariane 6: preparing flight VA264 for liftoff
summary: MetOp-SG-A1 travelled onboard the Canopée ship. Our teams at the European spaceport in French Guiana have been quite busy making sure both the rocket and the payloads are ready for flight VA264.
detailed_news: MetOp-SG-A1 is the first in a series of three successive pairs of satellites. Will provide global observations from polar orbit for weather forecasting and climate analysis for more than 20 years. Will launch on an Ariane 6 rocket from Europe’s Spaceport in Kourou, French Guiana on August 2025.

title: Live coverage: ULA to launch first national security mission on a Vulcan rocket
summary: The mission, dubbed USSF-106, will be the first Vulcan rocket launch since the vehicle was certified by the United States Space Force in late March. Liftoff from pad 41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station is schedule for 7:59 p.m. EDT (2359 UTC).
detailed_news: The United States Space Force (USSF)-106 mission is scheduled to launch from Cape Canaveral on Tuesday. The rocket will carry a pair of satellites to geoscynchronous orbit. The launch marks ULA's return to launching payloads as part of the National Security Space Launch (NSSL) program. The USSF-106 mission is comprised of two satellites. One of those remains a mystery with Space Force officials unwilling to provide any details. The other, which is described as the primary payload onboard the Vulcan rocket is the brainchild of the Air Force Research Laboratory. The mission and launch together come with a $250 million price tag. NTS-3 is being tested in the laboratory as well as out in the field. Some of the learns from this, like calibrating a spot beam antenna, can be applied to the next generation of GPS satellites, called GPS 3-F. The prime contractor that manufactured the satellite is L3Harris Technologies.

title: DGA Selects Infinite Orbits for €50M PALADIN Satellite-Inspection Service
summary:
France’s Directorate General of Armament has awarded the €50M PALADIN framework agreement to Infinite Orbits to deliver a geostationary orbit inspection and monitoring service for the nation’s Space Command. The PALADIN project is part of France’s Action et Résilience Spatiale (ARES – Space Action and Resilience) initiative, which aims to monitor and counter direct threats […]
The post DGA Selects Infinite Orbits for €50M PALADIN Satellite-Inspection Service appeared first on European Spaceflight.
detailed_news: PALADIN project is part of France’s Action et Résilience Spatiale (ARES – Space Action and Resilience) initiative. Infinite Orbits will develop a dedicated spacecraft capable of delivering the geostationary orbit inspection and monitoring service. The spacecraft is expected to be ready for launch by 2027.

title: CREAM: avoiding collisions in space through automation
summary: Earth orbit is becoming increasingly crowded. With over 11 000 active satellites and many thousands more expected in the coming years as well as over 1.2 million pieces of space debris greater than 1 cm, the risk of in-orbit collisions has turned into a daily operational concern. ESA is investing in automation technologies that can help satellite operators respond more effectively to collision risks.
detailed_news: Collision Risk Estimation and Automated Mitigation (CREAM) project is a key element of ESA’s Space Safety Programme. It aims to reduce the workload of operators, the number of false alerts and the response time of collision avoidance measures. Started in 2020, the project has now entered a critical phase of ground systems test operations and in-orbit demonstrations. Europe must have the ambition to have a space programme and a space agency that is world-class. Agenda 2025 will bring European space to the next level. To meet our ambitions we need to accelerate the use of space in Europe. The Zero Debris Community is a collaborative effort for a sustainable future in orbit.

title: Raptor 3 testing ramps up at SpaceX McGregor
summary:
SpaceX has ramped up its engine testing efforts at the McGregor test facility this past…
The post Raptor 3 testing ramps up at SpaceX McGregor appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The SpaceX McGregor test site, situated in the small town of McGregor, Texas, serves as the company’s primary rocket development and test facility for propulsion systems. SpaceX has ramped up its engine testing efforts at the McGregor test facility this past week, conducting a total of 24 Raptor engine firings and achieving multiple milestones in engine performance and durability. SpaceX performed a rigorous “torture test” on the vertical stand, firing a single Raptor engine 13 times in succession. In addition to the firings, observers noted increased engine traffic around the site. A Raptor 2 Vacuum engine bearing serial number 580 was seen multiple times between August 4 and 7.

All other elements […]
detailed_news: Media are invited to NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama, at 2 p.m. CDT Thursday, Aug. 14. Media will have the opportunity to capture images and video and speak to subject matter experts. This event is open to U.S. media, who must confirm their attendance with Jonathan Deal in Marshall’S Office of Communications at jonathan.e.deal@nasa.gov.

title: NASA Awards Second Human Health, Performance Contract
summary: NASA has selected KBR Wyle Services, LLC of Fulton, Maryland, to provide services to the Human Health and Performance Directorate at the agency’s Johnson Space Center in Houston, which focuses on astronaut health, occupational health, and research that could help mitigate health risks for future human spaceflight missions. The Human Health and Performance Contract 2 […]
detailed_news: KBR Wyle Services, LLC of Fulton, Maryland, will provide services to the Human Health and Performance Directorate. The contract will acquire support services for several programs, primarily at NASA Johnson. The total estimated value of the base period plus the optional periods is $3.6 billion.

title: NASA Explores Industry Possibilities to Raise Swift Mission’s Orbit
summary: To drive the development of key space-based capabilities for the United States, NASA is exploring an opportunity to demonstrate technology to raise a spacecraft’s orbit to a higher altitude. Two American companies – Cambrian Works of Reston, Virginia, and Katalyst Space Technologies of Flagstaff, Arizona – will develop concept design studies for a possible orbit […]
detailed_news: NASA is exploring an opportunity to demonstrate technology to raise a spacecraft’s orbit to a higher altitude. Two American companies – Cambrian Works of Reston, Virginia, and Katalyst Space Technologies of Flagstaff, Arizona – will develop concept design studies. The Neil Gehrels Swift Observatory was designed to observe gamma-ray bursts, the universe's most powerful explosions. Cambrian and Katalyst have each been awarded $150,000 under Phase III SBIR contracts for concept design studies. NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, manages the Swift mission in collaboration with Penn State, the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico, and Northrop Grumman Space Systems.

title: Launch Roundup: Vulcan and Ariane to launch ahead of Starlink missions
summary:
After a week of weather delays across the U.S, launch cadence increases as providers strive…
The post Launch Roundup: Vulcan and Ariane to launch ahead of Starlink missions appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: A SpaceX Falcon 9 is now scheduled to launch on Tuesday, Aug. 12, at 8:44 PM PDT (Wednesday, 03:44 UTC) from Space Launch Complex 4 East (SLC-4E) at Vandenberg Space Force Base (VSFB) in California. The Ariane 6 flying this mission is of the ‘62’ variant, meaning two strap-on solid rocket boosters will be attached to the 5.4 m diameter core stage. The payload for this mission will be the MetOp-SG-A1 satellite, operated by the European Organisation for the Exploitation of Meteorological Satellites. Starlink Group 10-20 will launch atop booster B1085 and will fly northwest, carrying a payload of 28 satellites for insertion into LEO. After launch, the booster will land on the SpaceX droneship Just Read the Instructions. Another Falcon 9 launch is scheduled for Friday, Aug. 15 is Starlink Group 17-5.

title: Space Station Cell Studies
summary: Science in Space August 2025 Cells are the basic building blocks of all living things, from single-celled bacteria to plants and animals containing vast numbers of them. Cells have adapted for a wide variety of settings and functions. Nerve cells in humans and animals, for example, have long, thin extensions that rapidly transmit signals, while […]
detailed_news: Cell biology is the study of cell structure, function, and behavior. For humans, scientists in this field explore the mechanisms of diseases from bone loss to cancer and work on developing treatments. Cell-based experiments on The International Space Station help identify how spaceflight affects people and other living systems. NASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery. Latest News from Space Station Research Space Station research and technology tools and information. Space Stationresearch.com: http://www.nasa.gov/space-station/news-and-information.

title: NASA Continues Search for Moon-Focused Sustainability Solutions
summary: NASA is accepting U.S. submissions for the second phase of the agency’s LunaRecycle Challenge, a Moon-focused recycling competition. The challenge aims to develop solutions for recycling common trash materials – like fabrics, plastics, foam, and metals – that could accumulate from activities such as system operations, industrial activities, and building habitats in deep space. Phase […]
detailed_news: NASA is accepting U.S. submissions for the second phase of the agency’s LunaRecycle Challenge. The challenge aims to develop solutions for recycling common trash materials. Cash prizes totaling $2 million are available for successful solutions. Estimates indicate a crew of four astronauts could generate more than 2,100 kilograms (4,600 pounds) of single-use waste.

title: Why Amazon is letting its rival launch its satellites
summary: Satellite companies find themselves between a rocket and a hard place.
detailed_news: SpaceX launched a direct competitor to its Starlink network into orbit. Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon, owns a rocket company of his own in Blue Origin. SpaceX sells launch services to all comers and typically offers the lowest price per kilogram to orbit. For SpaceX, this is great business. SpaceX asked companies seeking launch services to share spectrum rights as a condition of flying on Falcon 9. The term spectrum rights refers to using part of the radio frequency spectrum for transmitting data to and from space. Other companies, including AST SpaceMobile and EchoStar will need to decide whether to buy from SpaceX or pay more for slower access to space from other launch companies.

title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 Splashes Down in Pacific Ocean
summary: The members of NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 mission – Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov, left, NASA astronauts Nichole Ayers and Anne McClain, and JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi – are all smiles after having landed in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of San Diego, Calif., Saturday, Aug. 9, 2025. The crew spent seven […]
detailed_news: The crew spent seven months aboard the International Space Station. Crew-10 contributed hundreds of hours to scientific research, maintenance activities, and technology demonstrations. McClain, Ayers, and Onishi completed investigations on plant and microalgae growth, examined how space radiation affects DNA sequences in plants.

The agency states that on Mars, a flapping-wing propulsion system could offer greater energy efficiency, manoeuvrability, structural robustness, and adaptability than conventional helicopter or fixed-wing alternatives.

This timelapse video captures key stages from the encapsulation within the Ariane 6 fairing to the installation in the launch tower.

The European Commission’s Copernicus Sentinel-5 spectrometer is also onboard.

The missions will launch on an Ariane 6 with two boosters.

title: Juliana Barajas: Supporting NASA’s Mission, One Task at a Time
summary: As an administrative assistant in the Safety and Mission Assurance Office at NASA’s White Sands Test Facility in Las Cruces, New Mexico, Juliana Barajas approaches her work with one clear mission: to help others succeed.   For over two decades, she has supported NASA’s mission with a career grounded in service, perseverance, and gratitude. Whether coordinating […]
detailed_news: Juliana Barajas is an administrative assistant in the Safety and Mission Assurance Office at NASA’s White Sands Test Facility in Las Cruces, New Mexico. “If I can help those around me succeed, then I have fulfilled my duty,” she said. She hopes to pass on courage, resilience, and the determination to persevere.

title: Ariane 6 infographic: countdown to liftoff
summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: A lot happens before an Ariane 6 rocket takes off, especially in the last hours before launch. Ground pipes that supply the rocket with its propellants are chilled slowly to avoid stress on the system. Liquid hydrogen flows at –253°C! When the ground pipes are at temperature the upper and core stages are filled with propellants. Final weather checks are performed before an automated sequence starts.

summary: From the ESA Blogs.
detailed_news: The Ariane 6 launch pad is called ELA-4 for 'Ensemble de Lancement Ariane' It is the fourth launch pad built for Ariane launches from Europe’s Spaceport in French Guiana. E LA-4 was built from the ground up specifically forAriane 6, some previous generation Ariane rockets reused older launch pads.

title: Hera observes asteroids as DART reveals more about its destination
summary:
Travelling through the asteroid belt, the European Space Agency’s Hera spacecraft has taken its first…
The post Hera observes asteroids as DART reveals more about its destination appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: The European Space Agency’s Hera spacecraft has taken its first images of asteroids. The spacecraft is heading toward asteroid 65803 Didymos and its companion Dimorphos, on a mission to study the results of an intentional collision. The Double Asteroid Redirection Test (DART) crashed into Dimmorphos on Sept 26, 2022, intending to change the asteroid’'s course. Together, DART and Hera lay the foundations for future planetary protection missions. Team reprocessed to remove noise and enhance the visibility of individual pieces of debris. They identified 104 boulders ranging from 20 cm to 3.6 m in diameter, hurtling away from the asteroid at speeds up to 52 m/s. Many of these boulders were found outside the main dust plume, indicating that they might have originated from collisions with different parts of the spacecraft. Hera will deploy a pair of CubeSats that will help study the asteroids in more detail. The first, called Milani, will study the dust surrounding Dimorphos and take spectral images of both asteroids. The other spacecraft, named Juventas, will line up with Hera to perform radio science experiments and study the interior of Didymos. Missions like DART, Hera, and Ramses will help astronomers better understand asteroids and the threat they might pose to our planet and its inhabitants. These missions prepare space agencies and the space industry to quickly respond to these threats. All findings from these missions, including the tiny changes to Dimorphis’ orbital inclination, add to the body of knowledge that might eventually save our planet.

title: What’s Happening in Space Policy August 10-16, 2025
summary: Here is SpacePolicyOnline.com’s list of space policy events for the week of August 10-16, 2025 and any insight we can offer about them. The House and Senate are in recess […]
detailed_news: The 39th annual Small Satellite Conference, SmallSat, takes place for the first time somewhere other than Utah State University in Logan, Utah. About 4,000 people from 1,300 organizations and 45 countries are expected. On the launch front, the big event is ULA’s first Vulcan mission for the U.S. Space Force. We’re especially looking forward to Space News’ webinar on Space Based Solar Power (SBSP) NASA's Office of Technology, Policy and Strategy took a new look last year focused on whether SPS is an option to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions. The third panelist on Thursday, Martin Soltau, clearly disagrees. He’s co-CEO of Space Solar , a U.K. company whose “single corporate priority” is developing SBSP.

title: Live Coverage: SpaceX Falcon 9 to make another attempt to launch Amazon Project Kuiper mission
summary: Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida is scheduled for 8:57 a.m. EDT (1257 UTC), after three earlier attempts were scrubbed.
detailed_news: A SpaceX Falcon 9 will make another attempt Sunday to launch 24 satellites for Amazon’s Project Kuiper internet service. Liftoff from Space Launch Complex 40 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida is scheduled for 8:57 a.m. EDT (12:57 UTC) This will be the fourth scheduled launch attempt for the mission, designated KF-02. Spaceflight Now will have live coverage beginning about an hour prior to liftoff.

title: Crew-10 Splashes Down Off San Diego
summary: NASA’s Crew-10 splashed down in the Pacific Ocean this morning after five months on the International Space Station. Two private astronaut crews, Fram2 and Axiom-4, made West Coast splashdowns earlier […]
detailed_news: Crew Dragon Endurance landed off the coast of San Diego at 11:33 am EDT. SpaceX moved splashdowns from Florida to California to ensure that any surviving pieces of Dragon’s trunk, which separates during reentry, end up in the ocean and not on land. Two private astronaut crews, Fram2 and Axiom-4, made West Coast splashdowns earlier this year, but this is the first NASA crew to land there. NASA ISS Program Manager Dana Weigel said on August 1 that the Russian segment will be used for attitude control during the two-year process. The U.S. Deorbit Vehicle being built by SpaceX then will do the thrusting needed to direct the ISS into an unoccupied area of the Pacific Ocean in 2030.

title: NASA’s SpaceX Crew-10 Mission Returns, Splashes Down Off California
summary: The first crew to splash down in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California as part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program completed the agency’s 10th commercial crew rotation mission to the International Space Station on Saturday. NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut […]
detailed_news: NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, JAXA (Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency) astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Roscosmos cosmonaut Kirill Peskov returned to Earth at 11:33 a.m. EDT. Crew-10 contributed hundreds of hours to scientific research, maintenance activities, and technology demonstrations.

title: Crew 10 returns to Earth with Pacific Ocean splashdown
summary: Two NASA astronauts, a Japanese flier and a Russian cosmonaut plunged back to Earth Saturday, safely splashing down in the Pacific Ocean near San Diego to wrap up a five-month mission.
detailed_news: Two NASA astronauts, a Japanese flier and a Russian cosmonaut plunged back to Earth Saturday, safely splashing down in the Pacific Ocean near San Diego. The Crew 10 fliers undocked from the station’s forward port at 6:15 p.m. Friday, two days later than originally planned due to high winds.

title: Apollo 13 Astronaut Jim Lovell Passes Away
summary: Retired NASA astronaut Jim Lovell passed away yesterday at the age of 97. He will be long remembered as commander of Apollo 13, the historic 1970 mission to the Moon […]
detailed_news: Jim Lovell passed away yesterday at the age of 97. He will be long remembered as commander of Apollo 13, the historic 1970 mission to the Moon. Lovell’s first spaceflight was Gemini VII , a 14-day mission with Borman in 1965, the longest spaceflight at that time. title: Jim Lovell, Apollo 8 & 13 astronaut, dies at 97
summary: Lovell served as the pilot of the Command Module for Apollo 8 and the commander of the Apollo 13 mission. NASA said he died Thursday, Aug. 7, in Lake Forest, Illinois, a suburb of Chicago.
detailed_news: James 'Jim' Lovell, one of the last seven surviving Apollo astronauts, died on Thursday, Aug. 7, at the age of 97. A veteran of four spaceflights at the dawn of America’s human spaceflight program, he flew two missions in the Gemini program and then served on the crews of Apollo 8 and the ill-fated Apollo 13. NASA’s Perseverance Mars rover has been hoisted on top of its United Launch Alliance Atlas 5 rocket at Cape Canaveral for liftoff this month. Teams repaired a small leak on the launch vehicle and overcame delays caused by coronavirus cases among staff working on the mission. Kennedy Space Center will reopen for normal operations Friday.

title: NASA Selects Contractors to Supply Centers with Helium
summary: NASA has chosen a group of contractors to supply multiple agency facilities with liquid and gaseous helium for at least the next two years. The NASA Agency-wide Supply of Liquid and Gaseous Helium contract is a fixed-price indefinite-delivery requirements contract with firm-fixed-price delivery orders. The awards have a total estimated value of approximately $105.1 million. […]
detailed_news: The NASA Agency-wide Supply of Liquid and Gaseous Helium contract is a fixed-price indefinite-delivery requirements contract with firm-fixed-price delivery orders. The awards have a total estimated value of approximately $105.1 million. The performance period begins Wednesday, Oct. 1, to Sept. 30, 2027.

title: Legendary Apollo 13 Commander Jim Lovell Dies at 97
summary:
James “Jim” Lovell, the former NASA astronaut renowned for his heroic leadership during the ill-fated…
The post Legendary Apollo 13 Commander Jim Lovell Dies at 97 appeared first on NASASpaceFlight.com.
detailed_news: Lovell was the oldest living former astronaut following the death of Frank Borman in 2023. Lovell’s career began in aviation, where he flew fighter jets, including a Western Pacific deployment aboard the aircraft carrier USS Shangri-La. He first ventured into space with the Gemini program, flying on Gemini 7 in 1965 and Gemini 12 in 1966. He later served as command module pilot on Apollo 8, the historic first crewed mission to orbit the Moon, before commanding Apollo 13. The Apollo 13 mission was a "successful failure" The mission spurred major safety redesigns in later Apollo spacecraft. Lovell retired from NASA in 1973 and pursued a successful career in the commercial sector. “We will miss his unshakeable optimism, his sense of humor, and the way he made each of us feel we could do the impossible,” his family said.

title: NASA Astronaut Jim Lovell, First to Orbit the Moon and Survive Apollo 13 Crisis; Passes at 97
summary: NASA Astronaut Jim Lovell, First to Orbit the Moon and Survive Apollo 13 Crisis; Passes at 97
detailed_news: Lovell is one of only three people to fly to the Moon twice, and the only one who did so without ever landing on it. His memoir, Lost Moon, remains one of the most compelling accounts of the Apollo program and served as the basis for Apollo 13. Known among his peers as “Smilin’ Jim” for his sharp wit and easygoing demeanor, Lovell was admired for his unwavering optimism and approachability. Lovell is survived by his four children, and a legacy that has touched millions around the world. “Jim Lovell embodied the bold resolve and optimism of both past and future explorers, and we will remember him always,” - NASA’s Statement Survived by His Family

title: Acting NASA Administrator Reflects on Legacy of Astronaut Jim Lovell
summary: The following is a statement from acting NASA Administrator Sean Duffy on the passing of famed Apollo astronaut Jim Lovell. He passed away Aug. 7, in Lake Forest, Illinois. He was 97 years old. “NASA sends its condolences to the family of Capt. Jim Lovell, whose life and work inspired millions of people across the […]
detailed_news: Jim Lovell passed away Aug. 7, in Lake Forest, Illinois. He was 97 years old. Lovell was nicknamed Smilin’ Jim by his fellow astronauts because he was quick with a grin when he had a particularly funny comeback. “Jim’s character and steadfast courage helped our nation reach the Moon and turned a potential tragedy into a success from which we learned an enormous amount,” NASA says.

title: NASA Invites Media to View Heliophysics, NOAA Space Weather Missions
summary: NASA invites media to view the agency’s IMAP (Interstellar Mapping and Acceleration Probe) spacecraft and two other missions — the Carruthers Geocorona Observatory and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s (NOAA) Space Weather Follow On–Lagrange 1 (SWFO-L1) observatory, which will launch along with IMAP as rideshares. Media will have the opportunity to photograph the three […]
detailed_news: The IMAP mission will study the heliosphere, a vast magnetic bubble created by the Sun. Carruthers will use its ultraviolet cameras to monitor how material from the Sun impacts the outermost part of Earth’s atmosphere. The SWFO-L1 mission will observe solar eruptions, and monitor incoming space weather 24/7.
